headline.seo: At Birdland, Brandishing Passion’s Torch, Studiously

docs.snippet: Many of the people involved with "The Blind Side" have seen dividends from the movie's success....
docs.lead_paragraph: Like a cross between two Kevin Spacey movies (bonus points if you know which ones), "The Blind Side" has been paying it forward for everyone involved: Sandra Bullock got an Oscar nomination; the Tuohys, the Memphis family at the center of the story, got their own book deal, and Michael Lewis, the author of the account that started it all, got to see his movie career re-ignite after an adaptation of his baseball movie "Moneyball" wiped out last year. In fact Mr. Lewis, a contributing writer for Vanity Fair and The New York Times Magazine, should be riding twice as high right now: not only is "Moneyball" apparently back on track - with Brad Pitt still set to star and Bennett Miller ("Capote") to direct - but, according to New York magazine, Mr. Pitt has optioned Mr. Lewis's next book, "The Big Short: Inside the Doomsday Machine," about the housing bubble. None of this has absolutely anything to do with this year's Oscar race, by the way. And the answers are: "Swimming with Sharks" and "K-Pax."
docs.abstract: Many of the people involved with "The Blind Side" have seen dividends from the movie's success.

headline.main: The Inspirational Movie That Keeps On Giving

docs.snippet: While the AMC theater chain once again does its best-picture marathon, the IFC Theater is holding a "Bigelow vs. Cameron" midnight series....
docs.lead_paragraph: The 10 best picture nominees are not just shaking up the Oscar telecast. (A F.A.Q. for the Bagger: How are they going to fit in all those clips? A: Search us. Er, we'll find out!) The AMC movie theater chain, which has a tradition of holding a yearly best-picture marathon, is suffering some scheduling pains with all the extra films, according to an announcement on its Web site.
docs.abstract: While the AMC theater chain once again does its best-picture marathon, the IFC Theater is holding a "Bigelow vs. Cameron" midnight series.

docs.snippet: To bring down the median age of the Oscar viewer, making it more advertiser-friendly in the process, the Academy is pursuing a host of tactics....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, whose stodginess rivals a meter maid's, is joining the social media era. No Google Buzz just yet, but it is unveiling an iPhone app for the Oscars. It lists all the nominees with "valuable insider information" and allows you to see trailers for the best pictures and others, and to make and share your predictions for the winners.
docs.abstract: To bring down the median age of the Oscar viewer, making it more advertiser-friendly in the process, the Academy is pursuing a host of tactics.

headline.main: Oscar Chases the Youths of Today

docs.snippet: CIRKER--IRA, Esteemed Director-Producer of theatre and television passes at 86. Although Ira Cirker's directorial opus spanned from Shakespeare to soap operas to Stein, a constant in his eclectic career was his love of actors and the process of ac...
docs.lead_paragraph: CIRKER--IRA, Esteemed Director-Producer of theatre and television passes at 86. Although Ira Cirker's directorial opus spanned from Shakespeare to soap operas to Stein, a constant in his eclectic career was his love of actors and the process of acting. Emmy Award-winning actress Linda Dano wrote: "An exceptionally talented director, Ira Cirker understood the delicate balance between quality work, delicate guidance and friendship." His introduction to the world of theatre was as the youngest cast member of Moss Hart's "Winged Victory", a hit Broadway stage production during WWII. He also appeared in the Darryl Zanuck produced and George Cukor directed film. He began his directorial career as co-director with Oscar Homolka of Ibsen's The Master Builder and was assistant director to Burgess Meredith for the Actors Studio production on Broadway of James Baldwin's Blues for Mr. Charlie. He also assisted Jean Renoir for the film Elena et Les Hommes with Ingrid Bergman. A pioneer in the early days of live television, Ira Cirker directed shows such as Robert Montgomery Presents, Search for Tomorrow, Nash Airflyte Theatre, and Valiant Lady, and recounted the days when dream sequences were signaled by filming colored water stirred in a pail. For 17 years, Ira Cirker was the director of NBC's Another World and he became the first person in daytime television to direct the hour and 90 minute formats. In his tenure at Another World he was nominated for six Emmy awards and directed actors such as Linda Dano, Brad Davis, Morgan Freeman, Constance Ford, Ray Liotta, Anne Meacham, Douglas Watson, and Victoria Wyndham. He instituted a training program for directors in television and Melvin Bernhardt, Jack Hofsiss, Barnet Kellman, Jeff Bleckner, and Casey Childs all were under his tutelage. In Los Angeles in the 1960's he directed the controversial one acts by LeRoi Jones, Dutchman and The Toilet, and was the executive director of Theatre in the Parks where he directed an interracial version of Anthony and Cleopatra starring Diana Sands and Robert Lansing. In the aftermath of the Watts riots in Los Angeles, he and William DuBois established the Watts Training Center, educating young people for careers in television, theatre and film. In 1961, Ira Cirker directed the telecast of John Kennedy's Inaugural Gala in Washington, DC that featured Frank Sinatra as master of ceremonies, and in 1962 assisted in the production of the Kennedy birthday party that featured Marilyn Monroe singing Happy Birthday. Off-Broadway, he directed Take A Giant Step by Lou Petersen with Louis Gossett, Jr., A Mighty Man is He with Claudette Colbert, Clerembard with Tammy Grimes and Claude Dauphin, A Whisper in God's Ear with Alan Alda, Naomi Court by Michael Sawyer with Brad Davis, My Prince My King by Victor Wolfson in association with Lee Strasberg at The Actor's Studio, and Gertrude Stein and a Companionby Win Wells with Jan Miner and Marian Seldes, produced by Lucille Lortel. In 1986, Ira Cirker's company, Mitchon Productions, in association with Leonard Herbst and Tapestry Productions, produced Gertrude Stein and a Companion with Jan Miner and Marian Seldes for the Bravo network garnering an Emmy for Outstanding Entertainment Programming, a Silver Hugo Award and an American Video Award for Drama. In 1993, Ira Cirker was inducted into the National Academy for Television Arts and Sciences' Silver Circle. Mr. Cirker was a founding member of the Stage Directors and Choreographers Society and a member of the Directors Guild of America. He is survived by his business partner and companion Leonard Herbst, former wife Lenore DeKoven and their two sons, Mitchell and Jason, his grandchildren Marlon and Mia, and their mother, Christine. A memorial has been planned for April 15th.

headline.seo: Fashion Week Moves Tents, Stays Upbeat
headline.main: One Last Time, Fashion Under a Tent
headline.sub: As the tents go up in Bryant Park for the last time, designers hope to keep the magic alive.
headline.print_headline: When New York Met the World

keywords.value: Council of Fashion Designers of America
keywords.name: organizations

docs.snippet: Now that there are two fewer late night talk shows for Oscar nominees to appear on, the looser daytime shows are getting more play. But actors run the risk of rampant silliness....
docs.lead_paragraph: As we bravely soldier forth into a Conan-less world, and a Leno-less one (if only, and unfortunately, for just a few weeks), Oscar campaign publicists may be facing a drought of acceptable showcases for their clients. A chat-show stop is a necessary part of the final weeks of campaigning, to convince viewers, and, ideally voters, that the nominee is still relatable and, more importantly, fulfills the requisite storyline, like Cinderella or Huh, Never Thought It Would Happen To Me - see: Sandra Bullock on "Late Show With David Letterman" and Gabourey Sidibe as one of Mr. Leno's final guests.
docs.abstract: Now that there are two fewer late night talk shows for Oscar nominees to appear on, the looser daytime shows are getting more play. But actors run the risk of rampant silliness.

headline.main: The Desperate Quest for Talk Show Outlets

docs.snippet: The new instant-runoff system might boost the chances of "The Hurt Locker" over James Cameron's "Avatar."...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two more Oscar prognosticators have taken a look at the Academy and found that this year's race comes down to the voting processes. (If the Bagger were a different kind of blogger, we would say: TOLDJA.) At The New Yorker, Hendrik Hertzberg says that the new instant-runoff system might give "The Hurt Locker" a boost over its most likely competitor. "'Avatar' is polarizing," he writes. "So is James Cameron. He may have fattened the bank accounts of a sizable bloc of Academy members - some three thousand people drew 'Avatar' paychecks - but that doesn't mean that they all long to recrown him king of the world. (As he has admitted, his people skills aren't the best.) These factors could push 'Avatar' toward the bottom of many a ranked-choice ballot."
docs.abstract: The new instant-runoff system might boost the chances of "The Hurt Locker" over James Cameron's "Avatar."

headline.main: A Voting System to Dethrone the King

docs.snippet: In January, five new shows simultaneously opened at Macro, a contemporary art museum housed in a former brewery, where they'll be on view until April 5....
docs.lead_paragraph: At the moment, it might feel like Rome is swimming in contemporary art. Late last year saw the opening of the Zaha Hadid-designed Maxxi. And on Jan. 22, five new shows simultaneously opened at Macro, a contemporary art museum housed in a former brewery, where they'll be on view until April 5.
docs.abstract: In January, five new shows simultaneously opened at Macro, a contemporary art museum housed in a former brewery, where they'll be on view until April 5.

headline.main: In Rome, Contemporary Art Times Five
